captions.text:
I was just gonna keep it
for a little while.
You're an ogre, like my father.

He won't let me stay out late,
or play records, or anything.

Your fatherwon't let you
stay out late?
No, he's terrible.

Once I was out late at a party.
He called the cops.

Can you imagine?
He had the whole police force there.

By the way,
where is it that you live, Carol?
Over on Ramona. Why?

Oh, no! You thought I'd tell you
where I live?

Not me. Not old Carol.
The night is young.

And I'm not hittin' the rack
till I get a little action.
What do you keep lookin' at?
Who's that? You know him?

- He's followin' awful close.
- Grab on to something.

Hey, man, I'm sorry
if I scared ya.

You'd have to do a hell of a lot
more than that to scare me.

I been lookin' all over for ya.
Didn't nobody tell you?

I can't keep track of all you punks
runnin' around here backwards.

You're supposed to be
the fastest thing in the valley.

But that can't be your car.
It must be your mama's car.

I'm sort of embarrassed
to be this close to you.

I'm not surprised,
drivin' a field car.

Field car?
What's a field car?

A field car runs through the fields,
drops cow shit all over the place.
That's pretty good.

I like the color of your car, man.
What's that supposed to be?

A cross between piss yellow
and puke green, ain't it?

You call that a paint job,
but it's pretty ugly.

I'll bet you gotta sneak up on the pumps
just to get a little air in your tires.

At least I don't have to pull over
to the side just to let a funeral go by.
Funny. You know what?
Your car's uglier than I am!
That didn't come out right.

Come on, boy.
Let's go. Prove it.

Why don't you go out and try
to win yourself a few races?

Then you come on back
and I'll show you a few things.
Race him. You can beat him.

That's a tough-lookin' girl
you got with you, man.

Tryin' to pick up
a few extra bucks baby-sittin'?

Doll, come and ride with me--
in about ten years!

Leave her out of this.
This is between you and me.
He's really fast, isn't he?
Yeah, but he's stupid.

title: American Graffiti (7/10) Movie CLIP - Must Be Your Mama's Car (1973) HD

comments.author: Melody Charles

comments.text:
+Maximus Confese I don't think that multiculturalism is as big a problem as 
you think. I live in a small city whose residence is 90% homogenous white. 
It's not a factor in pedestrian mobility because no one here walks around 
anyways. Everyone gets around in vehicles and meet up via social media. 
That's different from traditional ways of meeting up which were varied. And 
technology seems to have done away with the need to walk to the social 
gathering at the wreck center or soda bar. Drive-in spots have become 
obsolete because of home entertainment, etc. At least that's how it seems 
to me.
comments.author: 1namrog

comments.text:
+Destiny Lopez This scene is from movie - it can't be made to depict a time 
period as it really was. It's drag race scene made dramatic. It 
wouldn't happen in real life without getting attention from indignant 
pedestrians. Irresponsible and daring stuff happened, just like crime and 
gang activity happened in 1950's USA. And there was all sorts of other 
problems. I think the reason why people today are overly cautious and less 
likely to walk around is because of media hype, and overdependence on cars. 
In the young America of the 50's lots of young men took pride in their cars 
as a sign of independence. But growing up they were more likely to walk 
from place to place instead of being transported by school buses and mom. 
The latter situation is too common nowadays, and lots of teenagers - male 
and female - get cars as presents. So the historical situations are 
different, but not in the ways you commented about.
comments.author: 1namrog

comments.author: William George

comments.text:
+Maximus Confese While you are making some valid points (I grew up in 
Switzerland so I know a thing or two about safe place to live), there was a 
lot of shit going around in the 50s in the U.S. Like, beating on your wife 
and children was considered discipline and law enforcement didn’t respond 
(domestic violence was not considered a crime only until the 70s). They 
didn't like the idea of children listening to "black music", mostly thanks 
to Jim Crow laws. Up to the middle of the 50s there were separate 
educational facilities for black children. And the list goes on.

hearing once.

comments.text:
Making the [distance] in [time]. As in "made the run to work in 20 
minutes". Making the [distance] in [distance] has never made any sense!

added magic (as compared to physics) I guess I'm asking too much! :)

comments.author: Patrick B

comments.text:
George Lucas was clever about the way he filmed "American Graffiti." 
 Instead of shooting it on standard 35mm, he shot it on 16mm and used a 
home made lense stencil to make it wide screen. You can only get 16mm film 
in 3 x 4 format. He ended up with a 16mm movie with only have the frame 
being used which was then transferred to create 35mm prints. He saved at 
least a million dollars doing it that way. ﻿
comments.author: ldchappell1

comments.text:
That Mel's has been gone a long time.. It looks like it's in the suburbs 
but that's actually downtown San Francisco near the central freeway 
overpass There's a Goodman's Lumber there now.  I went to Tamalpais High 
School in the early 70s when this movie was made.  I was in that gymnasium 
on the same day the scenes were shot. That was filmed on the last day of 
summer vacation prior to the 1972-73 school year.  I've used that same 
bathroom where Ron Howard was talking about college girls "putting out"  ﻿
comments.author: ldchappell1

comments.text:
Sorry Alec but you're wrong. Do you have the DVD or Bluray?  Read the 
credits at the end of the film.  The movie was shot in Marin County and 
Sonoma County. The only scenes shot in San Francisco are the Mel's scenes. 
That Mel's was torn down before the movie was released in 1973. The movie 
revived interest in Mel's and it reopened on Geary Blvd where it's still in 
operation today. I  know two people who had speaking parts in "American 
Graffiti" and I know a lot about the film.
comments.author: ldchappell1
